results.title: Trapping and heading
results.brief_description:
Episode no. 3 of Series “Pele: the master and his method”
Demonstrates trapping skills with cushioning, inside and outside-of-the-foot traps, sole and instep traps and trapping on the run. Also shows a variety of heading techniques including how to play heading tennis.

results.title: Trapped [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Melanie Coombs, Melodrama Pictures, Australian Film Commission and Trudy Hellier
results.brief_description: Jackie and Fran share a workplace, house, as well as the view into the prison next door. Together, with the two cell mates that watch them - Mat and Angus - they make two absurd couples who communicate via the radio and window voyeurism, vying for the best form of intimacy without physicality. Cast includes Jim Russell, Kate Atkinson, Genevieve Morris and Mark Wilson.

results.title: Transuranium elements
results.creator_credit: David W. Ridgway, Davidson Films and Hal Geer
results.brief_description: Reviews the historical problem of the placement of the transuranium elements in the periodic table. The properties of the new elements are demonstrated, and the Hilac, an instrument used in making elements of very high atomic number, is shown. The transuranium elements so far discovered re neptunium, plutonium, americium, curium, berkelium, californium, and einsteinium

results.title: Transportation: America's inland waterways
results.brief_description: Map animation techniques shows the vast inland waterway system of the United States, divided into those serving the cities of the Mississippi Basin; the Atlantic coast; the cities along the Gulf of Mexico; the cities of the Pacific coast; and the cities of the Great Lakes. The film studies the importance of these waterways to industry and farming, and shows types of goods transported and methods of transport.

results.title: Transportation: a ship comes home
results.creator_credit: Manfred Kirchheimer and Hudson Valley Film Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the complexity of modern ocean transportation as we observe the exacting manoeuvres, expert timing, and the alertness to every shift of wind and current that are necessary to bring the majestic liner ‘The United States’ into port at New York harbour.

results.title: Transportation
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society, Jim Larison and Elaine Larison
results.brief_description: This film illustrates some of the ways in which transportation affects - even shapes - our lives. Explores many modes of transportation, from private such as bicycles or cars, to public mass transit, such as buses and trains. Also looks at aeroplane, railroad and ship transport. Suitable for Middle-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Transport in plants and animals: capture of nutrients in plants and animals
results.creator_credit: Glen Foster, Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education and Shane Mulcahy
results.brief_description: 1. “Transport in plants and animals”. Explains how plants and animals transport their nutritional requirements internally. Similarities and differences between the transport methods are discussed. 2. “Capture of nutrients in plants and animals”. Every living organism needs a method of taking nutrients and of spelling waste products. This program examines which nutrients are esential to plants and animals and compares the system used to achieve this exchange of substances.
